@&#MAIN-TITLE@&#Lease expiration management for a single lease term in the apartment industry

@&#HIGHLIGHTS@&#


               
               
                  
                     
                        
                           
                           LEM aims to control the number of lease expirations to maximize revenue growth.


                        
                        
                           
                           We examine rental rate strategies considering LEM for apartments with a single lease term and demand uncertainty.


                        
                        
                           
                           We show that the use of LEM is a compromise approach.


                        
                        
                           
                           Numerical simulations are also included to illustrate the major results.


                        
                     
                  
               
            

@&#KEYPHRASES@&#

Revenue management

Pricing

Lease expiration management

Apartment industry

@&#ABSTRACT@&#


               
               
                  Lease expiration management (LEM) in the apartment industry aims to control the number of lease expirations and thus achieve maximal revenue growth. We examine rental rate strategies in the context of LEM for apartment buildings that offer a single lease term and face demand uncertainty. We show that the building may incur a significant revenue loss if it fails to account for LEM in the determination of the rental rate. We also show that the use of LEM is a compromise approach between a limited optimization, where no future demand information is available, and a global optimization, where complete future demand information is available. We show that the use of LEM can enhance the apartment building’s revenue by as much as 8% when the desired number of expirations and associated costs are appropriately estimated. Numerical examples are included to illustrate the major results derived from our models and the impact on the apartment’s revenue of sensitivity to the desired number of expirations and associated costs.
               
            

@&#INTRODUCTION@&#

Revenue management (RM) has been successfully employed by diverse industries (including the airline and hotel industries) to maximize revenue growth. Although the application of RM to the apartment industry has made significant progress there still exist some unique challenges, including lease expiration management (Wang, 2008).

Essentially, RM aims to ensure that companies sell the right product to the right customer at the right time for the right price (Cross, 1997). RM leverages on-hand inventory with demand by dynamically setting the prices for products at various time points to maximize the seller’s revenue. There are several key differences between the application of RM in the apartment rental industry and other industries, however, which explain why RM techniques used elsewhere cannot be easily transported to the apartment industry. Lease expiration management (LEM) is the discipline of controlling the number of lease expirations at each future time point by dynamically setting rental rates for current rentals and is an important consideration in apartment RM. An apartment manager needs to manage the rental rates of leases not only by leveraging the number of rooms to be rented to current demand, but also by matching expected demand in the future, at the time when these leases expire and the units are available to be rented again.

The rental rate of a lease is the monthly payment by the tenant, which can vary according to move-in date and the lease term (where ‘term’ specifies the length of time that a tenant will stay in an apartment) (Wang, 2008). Because a typical lease term lasts for months/years, the revenue accrued from a single lease makes up a large portion of the total annual revenue for an apartment complex. Consequently, the setting of rental rates becomes crucial and sometimes even risky for the apartment owner.

Like many other service industries, demand in the apartment industry often shows a seasonal pattern (Joseph & James, 1996). In addition, the change in realized demand is dependent upon the change of rental rates to some extent. The higher that rental rates are set, the lower the number of leases that will be signed and the lower the number of units are available to re-rent when their leases expire in the future. Because an apartment owner usually has a limited, fixed number of units to lease, traditional apartment RM focuses on setting optimal rental rates at each decision point by balancing demand and available units, with the objective of maximizing total revenue. The “optimal” current rental rates will determine the “optimal” number of leases to be signed, and, as a result, will influence the rental rates at the future time points when these expire. This propagating dependence of rent setting is referred to as the “ripple effect,” and is also common in other service industries (for example, hotels.) A direct implication of the ripple effect is that setting the rental rates for current leases influences the rental rates for subsequent leases; the apartment owner will incur a significant revenue loss if this effect is not considered in the rental rates decision.

In apartment RM implementation, demand forecasts play an important role in setting the optimal rental rates. If the future demand at any given rental rate could be forecast perfectly, then the rental rates for the subsequent leases could be set “optimally” with consideration of the ripple effect. In reality, however, it is almost impossible to forecast demand accurately; the resulting inaccuracy in demand forecast tends to increase over time. For apartments, in particular, this forecast inaccuracy becomes a major issue because of the long lease terms. Therefore, in a long term or even a finite time horizon, it is very difficult to set global optimal rental rentals for each rental time point.

While the RM field for hotel management is fairly mature, and might appear to be directly relevant to the apartment rental industry, hotels and apartments crucially have different lengths of stay. Specifically, hotels usually have shorter lengths of stay and thus a larger volume of transactions, while apartments have longer lengths of stay and a lower volume of transactions. The greater volume of historical hotel transactions and the shorter time horizons involved makes demand forecasting for short stays/rentals easier for hotels than for apartments. Consequently the implementation of RM in the apartment rental industry is hampered by the difficulty of demand forecasting.

To alleviate this problem, the practice of LEM has emerged in the apartment industry. Using prior experience or knowledge about predictable events, apartment operators often specify the number of leases desired to expire at different time points in the future. The rationale for the use of LEM is thus not only to improve the demand forecast with additional information, but also to better optimize the rental rates to enhance revenues. Fig. 1
                      below is an example of LEM from a leading apartment company. It illustrates LEM estimates at different points in time from Sept 2011 to March 2013. The apartment manager manually manages lease expirations, aiming to match the actual number of lease expirations to the desired number of lease expirations. The number of desired expirations for each future time point is determined by the manager’s experience and historical data. The actual number of lease expirations is counted based on the number of units of move-outs. If the actual number of expirations exceeds the desired number of expirations, the extra rooms have a high possibility of being vacant, resulting in vacancy costs; insufficient move-outs will lead to shortage costs. Fig. 1 illustrates how, in practice, an apartment manager tries to use rental rates to match the actual number of lease expirations with the desired number of lease expirations, so that he can maximize the total revenue growth while simultaneously minimizing vacancy and shortage costs. The magnitude of such costs is often defined by the gap between the desired number of lease expirations and the actual number of lease expirations.

LEM using the method described in Fig. 1 is a common practice for leading apartment companies in the United States, and has attracted growing interest in the apartment industry. Surprisingly and interestingly, theoretical studies on how to optimally set rental rates within the LEM framework remain scarce. To fill this gap, in this paper, we develop a Markov decision process (MDP) formulation of a dynamic pricing problem for controlling lease expirations, in which the apartment’s objective is to maximize the total expected revenue from customer leases over the finite horizon by setting the rental rates for a single lease term. Prospective tenants move in at different time points in a planning horizon all having the same lease term. A single lease term is the most widely used in the apartment industry in North America, with many apartment buildings requiring tenants to sign one-year leases due to regulations or convenience; many Canadian conventional apartments also require tenants to sign annual leases. We are interested in how to model LEM and how to merge LEM in an MDP model to improve revenues over an MDP model without LEM.

Most MDP models in the literature either find the limited optimizations, as do the models used here (see, for example, Amaruchkul, Cooper, & Gupta, 2007; Gupta & Wang, 2008; Sivalenka, 2010), or provide heuristics (for example, Bertsimas & Popescu, 2003; De Boer, Freling, & Piersma, 2002; Zhang & Cooper, 2009). These studies do not, however, account for the ripple effect that is captured in our model. Our analysis shows that the use of LEM for a single-lease term in an MDP model can improve revenues over an MDP model without LEM if the desired numbers of lease expirations can be properly specified, and the associated shortage and vacancy costs can be appropriately estimated.

The paper is organized as follows. Section 2 briefly reviews the related literature and Section 3 outlines problem description, notations and assumptions. The conditions under which the apartment company can enhance revenue through implementing LEM are discussed in Section 4. Section 5 discusses the strategy of rental rates and issues of LEM implementation. Numerical examples in Section 6 are included to illustrate the major results of the paper and a brief discussion on the implementation of LEM is given in Section 7. Conclusions are provided in Section 8. All proofs are provided in the Appendix A.

The application of RM in the apartment industry is relatively new, although RM has become increasingly successful in service industries, including airlines (Smith, Leimkuhler, Darrow, & Samuels, 1992), hotels (Baker & Collier, 1999; Bitran & Mondschein, 1995; Bitran & Gilbert, 1996; Goldman, Freling, Pak, & Piersma, 2003; Weatherford, 1995), car rentals (Geraghty & Johnson, 1997), retail (Federgruen & Heching, 1999), and air-cargo (Amaruchkul et al., 2007). The apartment industry faces similar challenges to these service industries, in selling perishable products or services with capacity constraints.

The present research is related to the literature on dynamic pricing in the context of RM. Dynamic pricing problems have been studied extensively in the economics, marketing, and operations literature. Here we review studies in the RM context that relate to our model. Bitran and Caldentey (2003) and Talluri and van Ryzin (2004) provide a detailed overview of dynamic pricing models in the context of revenue management (RM). Zhao and Zheng (2000) show a significant improvement in the expected revenue by using an optimal dynamic pricing policy over a single pricing policy. Gallego and van Ryzin (1994) analyze dynamic adjustment of price as a function of inventory and length of remaining sales period under stochastic demand. Zhang and Cooper (2009) develop an MDP formulation of a dynamic pricing problem for multiple substitutable flights between the same origin and destination, taking into account customer choice among the flights. Ozkan, Karaesmen, and Ozekici (2013) formulate a Markov Decision Process (MDP) to maximize expected revenues over a finite horizon considering the dependence of the distribution of demand on external conditions and derive results to a related dynamic pricing formulation. These studies, however, do not include the ripple effect. Unlike those papers, the dynamic pricing problem in this paper considers the impact of the pricing (rental rate) policy on both the current number of rooms to be rented with a capacity constraint, and the number of rooms available to rent in the future when the current leases expire. Thus, we consider the ‘ripple effect’ by including the costs of a mismatch between the actual number of expirations and desired number of expirations in our MDP models.

The research described here is also related to the application of RM in the apartment industry. The growing interest in apartment RM has been noted as a trend in multifamily property management (Sawh, 2012). Sawh (2012) pointed out that “although use of revenue management systems in the multifamily industry has initially been slow, interest and adoption has risen sharply in the past two years as companies strive to keep the revenue line as high as possible in a shrinking economy”. There have, however, been limited RM studies related to the apartment industry, in particular, to the use of LEM. While the apartment industry shares some similarities with the other industries, it faces its own unique characteristics (Wang, 2008). These unique characteristics, such as the ripple effect, lead LEM to being critical to the success of apartment RM. Sivalenka (2010) proposed the use of a linear programming (LP) optimization model to set rental rates. His model requires that future demand be known, which is not very useful in practice. As pointed out by Wang (2008), LEM has become important to apartment RM, but no theoretical studies have been done. The present paper makes the first theoretical contribution to the research stream on LEM in apartment RM by formulating LEM for a single lease term using MDP model to dynamically set rental rates over the planning horizon.

We model the problem of setting apartment rental rates in a finite horizon as a MDP. The model presented in Section 4 does not consider LEM which allows us to set up a benchmark case in which the traditional apartment RM sets the optimal rental rates for a single lease term. This section gives the condition when the MDP model without LEM is equivalent to a static model. We present the MDP model with LEM in Section 5. We show revenue enhancement for the apartment with LEM by comparison to the model without LEM. The discussion of the impact of shortage costs and vacancy costs on the dynamic pricing policy and the revenue of the apartment is also included. We carry out numerical experiments to compare the performance of the models with and without LEM. The examples show that the MDP model with LEM can significantly enhance the apartment’s revenue, as compared to the model without LEM.

Thus, the paper also contributes to the RM literature stream by proposing a compromise approach to improving revenue for apartments with only imperfect information on future demand, and by providing guidelines in setting rents under LEM for apartment RM practices.

We will discuss the two cases of RM without LEM and RM with RM.                            Proposition 1 
                           suggests that the apartment which only offers a single-lease term can set the optimal rent based on the number of units available.

                     , this implies that in the planning horizon with T periods, the apartment has enough capacity to allow all rents to be set at optimums, for which the corresponding demands will not be constrained by y

                                 ∗

                           N
                           )
                        
                      is thus independent of L. Therefore, 
                        
                           
                              
                                 r

                      will increase with L, suggesting that the apartment can increase its revenue by offering a longer lease term (L). However, this result is not necessarily true when C

                      is the demand realized at time τ at the optimal rent

                           )
                        
                     . y
                     
                        t
                      is therefore implicitly dependent on the lease term (L) when t
                     >
                     L. A further examination is needed to investigate how 
                        
                           
                              
                                 r
                              
                              
                                 t
                              
                              
                                 ∗
                              
                           
                           (
                           
                              
                                 x
                              
                              
                                 t
                              
                           
                           )
                        
                      changes with L.

Even for a single lease term, the apartment RM problem is still a network problem, due to the multiple move-in periods and lengths of lease terms. In practice, a static model is widely used to model a network RM problem by assuming that demand is known for all t in the planning horizon T. If this is the case, the problem in (1) can be formulated as a static model:
                        
                           (8)
                           
                              
                                 
                                    
                                       
                                          ER
                                          =
                                       
                                    
                                    
                                       
                                          
                                          E
                                          
                                             
                                                
                                                   
                                                      
                                                         max
                                                      
                                                      
                                                         
                                                            
                                                               p
                                                            
                                                            
                                                               t
                                                            
                                                         
                                                      
                                                   
                                                   
                                                      
                                                         
                                                            ∑
                                                         
                                                         
                                                            t
                                                            =
                                                            1
                                                         
                                                         
                                                            T
                                                         
                                                      
                                                   
                                                   
                                                      
                                                         p
                                                      
                                                      
                                                         t
                                                      
                                                   
                                                   
                                                      
                                                         LU
                                                      
                                                      
                                                         t
                                                      
                                                   
                                                   (
                                                   
                                                      
                                                         p
                                                      
                                                      
                                                         t
                                                      
                                                   
                                                   )
                                                
                                             
                                          
                                       
                                    
                                 
                                 
                                    
                                       
                                          st
                                          .
                                       
                                    
                                    
                                       
                                          
                                          
                                             
                                                
                                                   
                                                      p
                                                   
                                                   
                                                      t
                                                   
                                                
                                             
                                             
                                                ̲
                                             
                                          
                                          ⩽
                                          
                                             
                                                p
                                             
                                             
                                                t
                                             
                                          
                                          ⩽
                                          
                                             
                                                
                                                   
                                                      p
                                                   
                                                   
                                                      t
                                                   
                                                
                                             
                                             
                                                ‾
                                             
                                          
                                          ,
                                       
                                    
                                 
                                 
                                    
                                    
                                       
                                          
                                          
                                             
                                                y
                                             
                                             
                                                t
                                             
                                          
                                          =
                                          C
                                          -
                                          
                                             
                                                
                                                   ∑
                                                
                                                
                                                   τ
                                                   =
                                                   t
                                                   -
                                                   L
                                                   +
                                                   1
                                                
                                                
                                                   t
                                                   -
                                                   1
                                                
                                             
                                          
                                          
                                             
                                                U
                                             
                                             
                                                τ
                                             
                                          
                                          (
                                          
                                             
                                                p
                                             
                                             
                                                τ
                                             
                                          
                                          )
                                          
                                          if
                                          
                                          t
                                          >
                                          L
                                          ,
                                          
                                          
                                             
                                                y
                                             
                                             
                                                t
                                             
                                          
                                          =
                                          C
                                          -
                                          
                                             
                                                
                                                   ∑
                                                
                                                
                                                   τ
                                                   =
                                                   1
                                                
                                                
                                                   t
                                                   -
                                                   1
                                                
                                             
                                          
                                          
                                             
                                                U
                                             
                                             
                                                τ
                                             
                                          
                                          (
                                          
                                             
                                                p
                                             
                                             
                                                τ
                                             
                                          
                                          )
                                          
                                          if

                                          ⩽
                                          L
                                          ,
                                          
                                          and
                                          
                                          
                                             
                                                y
                                             
                                             
                                                t
                                             
                                          
                                          ⩾
                                          0
                                          .
                                       
                                    
                                 
                              
                           
                        
                     where ER is the total expected revenue from leasing C units over T periods and U
                     
                        t
                     (p
                     
                        t
                     ) is given by (2). Denote 
                        
                           
                              
                                 p
                              
                              
                                 t
                              
                              
                                 SM
                                 ∗
                              
                           
                        
                      as the solution of the optimal rent to (8).

Under the assumption that the rent at each t is given, Bertsimas and Popescu (2003) proved that the revenue gained from an MDP model is no higher than that from a static model. The above discussions on both high-capacity and low-capacity cases also suggest that for C
                     ⩾
                     E[
                        C
                     ], revenue gained from an MDP model in (1) is the same as that from a static model in (8). This is because in the MDP model 
                        
                           
                              
                                 p
                              
                              
                                 t
                              
                              
                                 ∗
                              
                           
                           (
                           N
                           )
                           =
                           max
                           
                              
                                 
                                    
                                       
                                          p
                                       
                                       
                                          t
                                       
                                       
                                          o
                                          ∗
                                       
                                    
                                    (
                                    N
                                    )
                                    ,
                                    
                                       
                                          
                                             
                                                p
                                             
                                             
                                                t
                                             
                                          
                                       
                                       
                                          ̲
                                       
                                    
                                 
                              
                           
                        
                      for all t
                     ∈[1,
                     T], which is also the solution to (8) in the static model, i.e., 
                        
                           
                              
                                 p
                              
                              
                                 t
                              
                              
                                 ∗
                              
                           
                           (
                           N
                           )
                           =
                           
                              
                                 p
                              
                              
                                 t
                              
                              
                                 SM
                                 ∗
                              
                           
                        
                     . Therefore, the implementation of LEM in an MDP model in (1) will not offer any revenue advantage. However, when C
                     <
                     E[
                        C
                     ], the static model in (8) can be used to derive a global optimum. Without the availability of future demand information, the MDP model without LEM in (1) does not consider the impact of current rent decisions on the number of future expirations and thus on the rent in the future, leading to a limited optimization. The approach might result in a situation where too many units are allocated in the beginning periods of the planning horizon, which will lead to too few units available for the later periods. Because the apartment tends to set the rents to satisfy the current demand, this approach does not accommodate for LEM in which both current and future demands are considered. To examine the revenue enhancement by LEM, in section 5 we only consider the case C
                     <
                     E[
                        C
                     ].

LEM is used to control the difference between the desired number of lease expirations (n
                     
                        t+L
                     ) and the actual number of lease expirations [U
                     
                        t
                     (p
                     
                        t
                     )] at time t
                     +
                     L by setting rent (p
                     
                        t
                     ) appropriately, in the hope of increasing revenue. The rent decision made at time t would directly impact the rent decision in the future at time t
                     +
                     L. In practice, n
                     
                        t+L
                      can be estimated based on prior experience or can be specified ad hoc.

In order to develop a rent strategy with LEM, we add two costs, 
                           
                              
                                 
                                    c
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                 
                                 
                                    v
                                 
                              
                              ⩾
                              0
                           
                         and 
                           
                              
                                 
                                    c
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                 
                                 
                                    s
                                 
                              
                              ⩾
                              0
                           
                         where 
                           
                              
                                 
                                    c
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                 
                                 
                                    v
                                 
                              
                           
                         denotes the unit vacancy cost over the lease term if there are more actual expirations than desired (U
                        
                           t
                        (p
                        
                           t
                        )>
                        n
                        
                           t+L
                        ) and 
                           
                              
                                 
                                    c
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                 
                                 
                                    s
                                 
                              
                           
                         denotes the unit shortage cost over the lease term if U
                        
                           t
                        (p
                        
                           t
                        )<
                        n
                        
                           t+L
                        . These costs are similar to the shortage and overage costs in the newsvendor problem: 
                           
                              
                                 
                                    c
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                 
                                 
                                    v
                                 
                              
                           
                         can be estimated as the cost of holding a vacant apartment (utilities, overhead cost and amortized depreciation cost, etc.) while 
                           
                              
                                 
                                    c
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                 
                                 
                                    s
                                 
                              
                           
                         can be estimated from the impact of rejecting a potential tenant. The LEM problem now becomes that of setting optimal rents considering not only the difference between n
                        
                           t+L
                         and U
                        
                           t
                        (p
                        
                           t
                        ), but also the impact of vacancy and shortage costs on revenues. In the current practice of LEM, the apartment operators only focus on setting rents such that U
                        
                           t
                        (p
                        
                           t
                        ) can be as close to n
                        
                           t+L
                         as possible. The total cost can be expressed as:
                           
                              (9)
                              
                                 
                                    
                                       c
                                    
                                    
                                       t
                                    
                                    
                                       v
                                    
                                 
                                 
                                    
                                       [
                                       
                                          
                                             U
                                          
                                          
                                             t
                                          
                                       
                                       (
                                       
                                          
                                             p
                                          
                                          
                                             t
                                          
                                       
                                       )
                                       -
                                       
                                          
                                             n
                                          
                                          
                                             t
                                             +
                                             L
                                          
                                       
                                       ]
                                    
                                    
                                       +
                                    
                                 
                                 +
                                 
                                    
                                       c
                                    
                                    
                                       t
                                    
                                    
                                       s
                                    
                                 
                                 
                                    
                                       [
                                       
                                          
                                             n
                                          
                                          
                                             t
                                             +
                                             L
                                          
                                       
                                       -
                                       
                                          
                                             U
                                          
                                          
                                             t
                                          
                                       
                                       (
                                       
                                          
                                             p
                                          
                                          
                                             t
                                          
                                       
                                       )
                                       ]
                                    
                                    
                                       +
                                    
                                 
                                 .
                              
                           
                        
                     

The problem of RM with LEM becomes the traditional RM problem when 
                           
                              
                                 
                                    c
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                 
                                 
                                    v
                                 
                              
                              =
                              
                                 
                                    c
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                 
                                 
                                    s
                                 
                              
                              =
                              0
                           
                        , that is RM without LEM, as discussed in Section 4.

Consideration of these two added costs influences how the apartment building manager controls future lease expirations. For example, at time t, in order to reduce the total cost in (9), if the rent in Proposition 1 leads to 
                           
                              
                                 
                                    U
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                 
                              
                              (
                              
                                 
                                    p
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                 
                                 
                                    ∗
                                 
                              
                              (
                              N
                              )
                              )
                              >
                              
                                 
                                    n
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                    +
                                    L
                                 
                              
                           
                        , then the existence of 
                           
                              
                                 
                                    c

                         by (21)–(23). If the apartment is aware that

                        (21)–(23) indicate that

In a planning horizon with T periods, if the apartment manager starts by allocating a capacity of C units, then

                         in the beginning periods. Points (i) and (ii) in Proposition 4 suggest that with LEM, if 
                           
                              
                                 
                                    p

                         should ensure that

                         when 
                           
                              
                                 
                                    c

                              )
                           
                         will cause the apartment to have fewer units available for later periods prior to any leases expiring (for t
                        ⩽
                        L), as compared to the case without LEM. Therefore, with LEM and 
                           
                              
                                 
                                    x
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                 
                                 
                                    v
                                 
                              
                              >
                              0
                           
                        , at the beginning periods, the apartment can set a higher rent 
                           
                              
                                 
                                    p
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                 
                                 
                                    o
                                    ∗
                                 
                              
                              (
                              W
                              )
                              >
                              
                                 
                                    p
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                 
                                 
                                    o
                                    ∗
                                 
                              
                              (
                              N
                              )
                           
                        . Also, without knowing future demand, RM without LEM will focus on finding limited optimal by setting lower rents to attract more demand because there are abundant units available. As a consequence, there will be insufficient units for late periods prior to any leases expiring (t
                        ⩽
                        L). With LEM, however, higher rents might be set for the beginning periods so that there could be more units available for leasing for late periods prior to any leases expiring (t 
                        ⩽
                        L). In addition, Proposition 4 also indicates that a higher rent should be set if 
                           
                              
                                 
                                    y
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                 
                              
                              -
                              
                                 
                                    Λ
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                 
                              
                              
                                 
                                    
                                       
                                          
                                             z
                                          
                                          
                                             t
                                          
                                       
                                       
                                          
                                             
                                                
                                                   
                                                      p
                                                   
                                                   
                                                      t
                                                   
                                                   
                                                      vv
                                                      ∗
                                                   
                                                
                                             
                                          
                                       
                                    
                                 
                              
                              ⩾
                              
                                 
                                    n
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                    +
                                    L
                                 
                              
                           
                         since 
                           
                              
                                 
                                    p
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                 
                                 
                                    vv
                                    ∗
                                 
                              
                              >
                              
                                 
                                    p
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                 
                                 
                                    y
                                    ∗
                                 
                              
                              (
                              N
                              )
                           
                        .

With LEM, the apartment is able to set the “right” rents, which are neither too high to put off potential tenants nor too low to have too more vacant units. When attracting potential tenants becomes dominant for the apartment manager and 
                           
                              
                                 
                                    c
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                 
                                 
                                    s
                                 
                              
                           
                         is high, the manager can set a higher n
                        
                           t+L
                         that satisfies 
                           
                              
                                 
                                    x
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                 
                                 
                                    s
                                 
                              
                              >
                              0
                           
                         at time t, leading to a lower lease rate. A revenue loss might, however, be incurred if n
                        
                           t+L
                         does not reflect demand at time t
                        +
                        L, as compared to the case without LEM. Similarly, when enhancing potential revenue by discouraging potential tenants dominates and 
                           
                              
                                 
                                    c
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                 
                                 
                                    v
                                 
                              
                           
                         is high, the apartment can set a lower n
                        
                           t+L
                         that satisfies 
                           
                              
                                 
                                    x
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                 
                                 
                                    v
                                 
                              
                              >
                              0
                           
                         so that a higher rent can be set. Therefore, by estimating 
                           
                              
                                 
                                    c
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                 
                                 
                                    v
                                 
                              
                           
                         and 
                           
                              
                                 
                                    c
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                 
                                 
                                    s
                                 
                              
                           
                        , the apartment manager can attain a balance between attracting and putting off potential tenants by setting a reasonable n
                        
                           t+L
                         in implementing LEM.

                                    t

                              holds, the apartment can achieve the maximum incremental revenue by implementing LEM, and the resulting revenue is equal to that for the static model.
                           

Unlike the case without LEM, the setting of rents in the case with LEM depends on the desired n
                        
                           t+L
                        , and costs 
                           
                              
                                 
                                    c
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                 
                                 
                                    v
                                 
                              
                           
                         and

                                    t
                                 
                                 
                                    s
                                 
                              
                           
                        . With Proposition 6, the implementation of LEM allows the apartment to arrive at a solution which is between the solution of a global optimization (from the static model with full demand information) and the solution of a limited optimization (from the MDP model without LEM and future demand information). To achieve this, the apartment can use an MDP model with LEM by setting n
                        
                           t+L
                        , which reflects partial future demand information.

Implementing LEM raises an important issue on properly specifying n
                        
                           t+L
                        . A proper value of n
                        
                           t+L
                         should satisfy the condition of n
                        
                           t+L
                        
                        ⩽
                        d
                        
                           t
                        (
                           p
                           
                              t
                           
                        ) because d
                        
                           t
                         (
                           p
                           
                              t
                           
                        ) is the maximum expected number of units that can be rented out at time t. Since the specification of n
                        
                           t+L
                         takes into account future demand information, we can expect that this will affect revenue significantly when LEM is implemented. In the case of a “
                           perfect-match,
                        ” future demand information in the planning horizon is assumed to be available. In practice, however, it is very difficult for the apartment to obtain such a perfect-match solution because of extremely long lengths of stay in the apartment industry. In addition, future demand can be significantly influenced by many other factors, including changes in the economic situation and competition from other apartments. This cautions the apartment that a good LEM implementation is highly dependent on good knowledge and experience in estimating the future demand level in order to specify n
                        
                           t+L
                        . We argue that if the specification of n
                        
                           t+L
                         does not properly reflect future demand, the apartment may even experience a revenue loss if 
                           
                              
                                 
                                    c
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                 
                                 
                                    v
                                 
                              
                           
                         and 
                           
                              
                                 
                                    c
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                 
                                 
                                    s
                                 
                              
                           
                         are high. Furthermore, with a limited capacity (C) and no lease expirations for 1 ⩽
                        
                        t
                        
                        ⩽
                        L, we expect that no more than C leases will expire for any mL
                        +1⩽
                        t
                        ⩽
                        mL
                        +
                        L, for m
                        =1,2,…. Thus, a rational set of n
                        
                           t+L
                         should also satisfy 
                           
                              
                                 
                                    ∑

                                    =
                                    (
                                    m
                                    -
                                    1
                                    )

                                    n
                                 
                                 
                                    t
                                    +
                                    L
                                 
                              
                              ⩽
                              C
                           
                         for m
                        =1,2,…
                     

We now use numerical examples to illustrate the main results discussed in this paper. In Example 1, we will illustrate the impact of LEM on the rental rate policy and the revenue of the apartment in the “perfect-match” case with deterministic demand. The numerical example will compare rental rate strategies over the planning horizon in the cases with LEM to the case without LEM, and examine the increase in apartment revenue with implementation of LEM. The sensitivity analysis in this example will examine the changes of revenue with LEM with vacancy costs. In Example 2, we examine how the number of desired expirations will affect the performance of LEM and we will do a sensitivity analysis on how the revenue gain from implementing LEM changes with shortage costs. The results of this example imply that the manager should specify a reasonable set of numbers of desired expirations when the apartment implements LEM using the model that is presented in this paper. In Example 3, we compare the results from implementing LEM in the case with stochastic demand to the case with deterministic demand. We show that demand uncertainty reduces revenue enhancement as compared to the deterministic demand case.

In the following examples, we assume that an apartment building with capacity (C
                     =40units) offers a single lease term (L
                     =6months) in a planning horizon (T
                     =24months). The deterministic (or expected) demand is assumed to be a linear demand, d

                     (p

                     =0.02 for all t and a

                        p

                        Fig. 3 shows that the apartment manager will set a high price when demand is favorable, for cases both with and without LEM. In the case without LEM, the manager tries to lease as many units as possible for each period by adjusting the rental price without considering the impact of the current decision on the future (myopic behavior). The case with LEM considers information on future demand and aims to meet the projected demand with future vacancies by controlling the number of expirations with dynamic pricing. Fig. 4
                         shows revenue increase with c
                        
                           v
                         for this numerical example.

The revenue for the case without LEM is $683,550. The revenue for the case with LEM remains $739,431 for c
                        
                           v
                        
                        >
                        x
                        
                           v
                        
                        =4626, which is the same as the revenue from the static model in (8). The associated vacancy cost (c
                        
                           v
                        ) reflects the degree to which the apartment “discourages” lease expirations. In this example, the apartment can gain a maximum of 8.175% improvement in revenue by implementing LEM, as compared to the case without LEM.

The example also shows that the implementation of LEM in the apartment enhances its revenue. When 
                           
                              
                                 
                                    c
                                 
                                 
                                    v
                                 
                              
                              >
                              max

                        , the rental rates given by Proposition 3 are unchanged with the value of c

                         in this example; as a result, the revenue is unchanged with the value of c
                        
                           v
                        .

@&#DISCUSSION@&#

This research show that as compared to the case without LEM, RM with LEM changes the lease rates through anticipating the number of desired expirations and costs of shortage and vacancy. As a result, the implementation of LEM allows the apartment operator to compromise between solutions from a global optimization (LP model with full demand information) and a limited optimization (MDP model without LEM and no future demand information), under the condition of the lack of future demand information. To achieve this, the apartment operator can use an MDP model with LEM by setting the anticipated number of desired expirations and associated shortage and vacancy costs (taking into account partial future demand information).

In the case without LEM, without future demand information, the lease pricing decision at time t (determining the number of units to be signed at time t) is “myopic” and does not take into account the impact of the decision on the future time when these leases expire. With LEM, the apartment operator considers the impact by anticipating the number of desired expirations (reflecting partial future demand information) and estimating its “fitness to the future demand” through setting associated shortage and vacancy costs. The associated shortage and vacancy costs, therefore, reflect the degree to which the apartment “discourages” or “encourages” lease expirations. The more accurate the reflection of the future demand pattern by specifying the desired numbers of lease expirations, the more revenue the apartment can obtain from MDP model with LEM. The present research also raises a cautionary note for the apartment manager; if the desired numbers of lease expirations cannot be properly specified, in some extreme cases the MDP model with LEM can result in a revenue loss for the apartment (as illustrated in the second numerical example). As long as the desired number of lease expirations can be properly specified, and the associated shortage and vacancy costs can be appropriately estimated, the apartment can employ MDP model with LEM to improve revenue.

@&#CONCLUSION@&#

In practice, forecasting future demand accurately for the apartment industry is difficult. The use of LEM is an attempt to utilize knowledge about future demand through the prescription of the desired numbers of lease expirations (based on demand forecasting). This research shows that implementing LEM is an interesting compromise between limited optimization (from an MDP model without LEM, in which no future demand information is available) and global optimization (from a static model, in which all future demand information is disclosed). We show that if the desired number of lease expirations reflects real future demand to a high degree, the use of LEM can indeed significantly enhance apartment revenues. This research also suggests that the manager can rationally set the desired number of lease expirations and thus adjust the rental rates in consideration of the desired numbers of lease expirations, shortage and vacancy costs.

There are several implications of this research. With the lack of perfect future demand information, the apartment can implement LEM by arriving at a set of the desired numbers of lease expirations based on prior experience or historical data, along with consideration of shortage and vacancy costs, to enhance revenue. To accurately estimate future demand and to evaluate the goodness-of-fit between the desired numbers of lease expirations and future demand, the apartment should carefully assess the desired numbers of lease expirations and the shortage and vacancy costs. This research also shows that implementing LEM can be a revenue enhancing approach, and highlights the needs for the apartment facing an unknown future demand to take possible future information into consideration through the setting of the desired numbers of lease expirations in the rent decision. LEM allows the apartment to leverage the rent to manipulate lease expirations at different points of future time to meet the demand.

LEM can also, of course, be applied in other industries. For example, if a special event, such as a 5-day conference, is planned for a hotel, a certain number of rooms need to be blocked. The hotel manager thus has to control guest stays so that enough rooms will be available for the event. The use of LEM can maximize the revenue opportunity via the control of length of stay.

In this paper, we only discuss the use of LEM for a single lease term. Future research can extend this single lease term to multiple lease terms, and the presence of competition can be taken into account.

@&#ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS@&#

The authors gratefully acknowledge the anonymous referees whose comments improved this article, and financial support from the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada.
